Only had shells from about 8 bodies to use but that worked fine.  Decided to let it sit on the burner overnight.  Pros:  excellent flavor.  Cons:  entire house smelled of shellfish for many hours after!  Wish I had use for the extra as much was left over (used it for the risotto dish.)

Incredibly tasty.  Used homemade lobster stock from NYT recipe.  Added a bit more lobster meat than called for because it was available.  Thought I had chives but didn't.  And we don't eat cheese so that was left out *but* the addition of about a generous 1/2 cup or more of peas added both color and a little pizzazz.  Would definitely make it again.  Great hit with guest.

This is a comment more on David's description of antipasto than on the above recipe. He has hit it right on the nose; I've never seen a better and more accurate portrayal of this Italian intro to a meal. Congratulations!

The screaming, screaming, screaming children I put up with on a flight out of Sicily were mostly German, with some who were German and Italian.

The notion that Euro kids are better behaved than American kids is just surreally false.

I don't doubt that Europe is more child-friendly, but the kids there, overall, are also much better behaved.  If there's a parent on an airplane making their baby squeal with delight at the top of his/her lungs, thinking that because they find it so endearing, the rest of the airplane will too, there's a 99.9% chance that parent is an American.  I lived in Europe for over 10 years, and I didn't find the children I encountered out in public there to be annoying.  Here, quite often I do, because they are being loud or boisterous in a way that seems unnecessary to me, but usually seems to be totally acceptable or imperceptible to their parents.
It's an offensive word, but it's in quotation marks & attributed (however vaguely) to others.
Exactly!  Park Slope is a prime example.
Actually, if you look closely, you will see quite a bit of diversity in the suburbs today.

I see the opposite. These kids are at least as independent in the city as their less well-off peers. This comment — like many others — seems like silly class envy. As for "SUV-sized strollers": I can't see the harm in a parent wanting a nice stroller for their kids.

Honestly, I think many people in NY have had it with the entitled stroller set. It's one thing to have a child or two. It's quite another to think that having a child gives one the right to disrupt everyone else's lives with poorly behaved children and SUV-sized strollers. I see more and more people rolling their eyes at these screaming (white, spoiled) children who are constantly melting down in the streets, restaurants, stores, and subway.

I'm not sure why these people want to live in the city when they (and their values) so clearly belong to the suburbs. It used to be that the kids who grew up in the city had street-smarts and that this separated them from their blander suburban counterparts. Those days are long gone now as suburbanite parents clog our city with their neurotic helicopter parenting, a smothering so extreme that it's not uncommon to see ten year olds wheeled around the city like little members of a royal family, their legs so long that their $200 sneakers scrape along the pavement as they are (gently) pushed from behind.

These rich (white, corporate, bland) parents seem to think they are too cool and sophisticated to move to the suburbs. A quick glance in the mirror, however, would prove that thought wrong.
"spinster couples" is an oxymoron. I think you meant to say child free.

except on Saturday & Sunday !!

When was the last time a Police Union spokesman admitted that the police may have done something wrong?  They are always perfect, justified, and unappreciated.  I have no problem with police having good pay and benefits.  I just wish they'd lose the perfection stance.  It would be so refreshing to hear that they are looking into improving procedures so that arrests go down without injuries, and so that situations are defused rather than escalated.  The good cops must begin to speak out against misconduct and be ready to clean up their side of the street.  The Union issue is a red herring. It's the culture.

Why all the moms roaring down the street weekdays with doubledecker baby buggies, with foam rollers, yoga mats, shopping bags, water bottles and all sorts of other doo dads hanging off the sides, nipping peoples' heels.

Whether or not "bitter" is the right word, there is certainly a sense that she can easily imagine an alternative that might have been much better. But who can't imagine a better childhood, father, mother, wife, or sibling? Very few persons. I wonder to what extent this widespread dissatisfaction is an American thing. Myself 56 years old, I have recently lapsed into post-mortem analysis of most of the relationships around me. I know not a single male friend my age who has a vibrant and good (rather than merely functional and window-dressed conventional) relationship with his father. (My own died when I was 6 and though I now get choked up sometimes --watching movies-- that portray what none of my friends actually have; more often I am was able to live my very unconventional life without some dominant voice telling me what to do.) Likewise, most of my male friends are totally dissatisfied with their spouses or have ended up divorced—ecstatic with joy for their kids, but alienated from the partner with whom they produced and reared them. (I myself have never married — having never obtained what Kant called "economic puberty" — like the author herself, I took deep refuge in books, got my PhD in Greek and Latin, and delight in my solitude — more fearful of being miserable than lonely.) Life is tough; intimate relationships are even tougher. (I myself have won what intimacy comes from life-long friend who never crowd but before whom my heart is an open book.) Great article.

Wow! Even from across the Atlantic, never having met this woman, you are quite glibly offering her your opinion of her feelings.
I think you spent too much time with the psycho-ists developing an inflated ego.
Bitter? Are you kidding? She doesn't seem bitter at all. Just wise and hilarious.

Therapists are human, too, and have all the problems their patients do. My dad was a psychiatrist and saw patients in the house. While he studiously avoided psychoanalyzing me, there was lots of talk with colleagues and me about the issues of life, less in jargon than in humanistic and personal terms. He was open-minded, maintained high standards, and respected who I am and the way I chose. OK, he was provocative and questioning and had his own issues, but I am grateful for his sensitivity, caring, and intelligence. He asked the right questions.

It is a pity that Ms. Lamb-Shapiro is so bitter about her upbringing, but I think it is more about multiple divorces than all those therapists.

I think that your observations are correct, Charles. I live in a small mountain town, Westwood, a little more than a mile in elevation, and our water comes from a spring above Clear Creek. The water is still ice cold when it comes out of the faucet. That spring has been doing what springs do since the later 1930s when all of this was a logging area. That spring shows no sign of shutting down anytime soon.

The population here in the state uses 20% of the water and AG uses 80% of the water, year to year. This silly water allocation setup is a product of the later 1800s. It's a "taken for granted" thing that no longer has any merit at all. Growing tomatos in a desert? Come on... Almonds? I'm 67 and I don't belive that I ever ate an almond; at least not on purpose, anyway.

I left southern California (the first time) in 1974 (1967/1974) and went about consulting in NC, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Page, AZ, the Mescalero Apache reservation in Mescalero NM and then somehow, when I retired, I found myself here in these mountains. I was born in Newport, RI. Toward the end of my wanderings I must not have been paying attention to where I was going. The land of high taxes and where gasoline has always been a dollar higher per gallon than it is anywhere else. Foolish on my part. I must have forgotten.

I bought a house up here in early 1990, retired after my last stint in Ruidoso, NM in late 2001.

Well, Fiorina is the Sarah Palin of 2016, and, Romney is Romney, having a luxurious home in San Diego. We need intelligent people to devise solutions.

My concern is that the severity is cyclical, so that while we'll see a return to the snowpack, the next drought will be even worse than this one. This is beyond the capabilities of Fiorina or Romney to understand, although the they are incredibly wealthy, which makes them far better people than I am.

Ag is on the radar screen. One of the reasons is the big growth in populatios. Cal has built a lot of houses. In days of yore, such as the early '90's, ag's use of water might have been more tolerable. It's like the fires. Fires were tractable, but as people moved into the fire areas they became more serious.

Someone's going to have to reduce the size of agriculture by a vast amount. No one is capable of doing that. But,,, by how much does one reduce it? If the drought is to continue, and the population growth, along with the wealth that uses large amounts of water, continues, Cal will be in the same difficulty.

We could outsource ag the way we do jobs due to cost. That would leave more water for lMr. Rabbani-Shirazawns and those wonderful town medians that make NJ look like a slum. It looks to me like ag has to downsize, but it's wise for Californians to work together on a sweeping water consumption plan.
If I had a group of friends in LA, I would cash in on the absurd real estate bubble here and head west in a NY minute.

I moved from New Jersey to California 50 years ago, I have seen huge changes in California, largely due to all the new people moving here, and once here, they later move to less crowded areas and mess things up.  My last move was from San Diego to Lake Arrowhead.  Please do not move to Lake Arrowhead, don't even visit Lake Arrowhead.  The roads are dangerous, we don't have shopping malls, we have lots of trees .... I've said too much already.

There is no way she rented an entire 2 bedroom HOUSE with workshop AND garage for $1250 (*unless she time traveled here from 1989). That amount would hardly rent her a junior one-bedroom apartment in a shabby building, let alone a house with rentable extra space!

Either that is HER SHARE of the rent (with at least one roommate) OR she is renting from her grandmother or another family member.

What troubles me is the idea of some naive young New Yorker reading this, and rushing off to Echo Park, expecting to find rental listings in this price range with 2 bedroom HOUSES, rather than the truth, which is about 2-3 times as costly.

The short version: prices in LA are just as bad as NYC, but you do get a bit more space. The downside is you MUST have a car, whereas in the NYC you can depend on public transit.
Loma Linda is a small community centered around a VA hospital and The Loma Linda University Medical School and Medical Center, about 60 miles from L.A.  Two bedroom apts rent for $900 per month.

I do not believe that the woman in the article found a 2-bedroom bungalow in Echo Park for $1,250. If she did, it was a complete anomaly and probably didn't have parking or laundry facilities. Decent 2-bedrooms are going for at least $2,500, so please New Yorkers, do not think you'll get a great deal in one of the groovy neighborhoods. You'll have to live in the outskirts of the grooviness for that. A nice 1-bedroom in Silver Lake is at least $1,800. Of course, there are exceptions, but not many.

Money is suppose to be a representation of a Society's goods and services in a perfect free market thus eliminating the barter system.  However in real economies money often doesn't represent a Society's goods and services.  Inflation is too much money chasing to few goods.  A Depression is not enough money chasing a Society's goods and services.  In Baltimore we see the impacts of poverty and how it leads to other societal problems. Increasing aid to the poor through more Food Stamps, Universal Medicaid and a much higher Earned Income Tax Credit would in our current state of Depression boost our economy while directly reducing poverty though government aid thus indirectly reducing poverty through economic expansion.
